_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Farm Service 

233 West Ciro Street

PO Box 68

Truman, MN 56088

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The Coop board, management and employees at Central Farm Service (CFS), 77 Cedar Street, Easton, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information and Regulated Substance:



The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, handled and distributed for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients.  CFS-Easton also periodically retains two OUTSIDE contractors who utilize mobile units for the purpose of blending anhydrous ammonia with phosphoric acid to produce a non-hazardous liquid fertilizer, 10-34-0.  CFS is neither involved in the conversion process, nor does CFS own the conversion equipment.  Raw materials used in the conversion process include anhydrous ammonia, super phosphoric acid and water. When one of the contractor's portable conversion equipment arrives at the site to conduct the conversion, CFS Easton's RMP is meshed with the contractor's PSM to satisfy regulatory requirements during the conversion process. 



The facility has two 18,000 gallon storage tanks and one 30,000 gallon (recently added) storage tank for a maximum quantity of BULK ammonia storage of approximately 308,000 pounds; and approximately 135,000 pounds of additional storage is available in 1,450 gallon nurse tanks.  The maximum quantity handled at one time would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.



This facility is not constantly manned every work day.  Approximately 10

or so different employees may work on the site periodically throughout the year.  The best estimation of full-time equivalency would be 1-2 employees. 





3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Department of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload equipment, and perform any needed maintenance to the equipment found during the inspections. 



As it relates to Process two and Process three (conversion to 10-34-0 by outside contractors) our contractors have provided CFS with information to support they have a mechanical integrity program in place along with written operating procedures, safe work procedures, emergency action plan and a training program. 



4. The Five-year Accident History PROCESS 1 - HANDLING AND STORAGE:  



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years on site that have: 



a) Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or 

b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.





4.  The Five-year Accident History PROCESS 2 and PROCESS 3 - CONVERSION OF 10-34-00 BY OUTSIDE CONTRACTORS (MOBILE UNIT)



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have:

a) Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility in question during the conversion process; or 

b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage at the facility in question during the conversion process.  



Howe

ver, both the conversion contractors have identified NON-CFS Easton site incidents in their safety information; and therefore, in turn CFS Easton noted this in Section 8, Process #2 and Process #3.  



5. The Emergency Response Program:  



The facility has:



a. A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95. The plan includes a specific section on NH3 Releases and what to do in the event of a release. The next annual emergency action plan training is scheduled for July 2015. Additional emergency response training is also provided at three other training sessions held at CFS on an annual basis.  One of these three sessions is held each fall and is just on anhydrous ammonia safety.



b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



c. Coordinated with local emergency responders.



d. A Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information for quick access and reference.



e. A Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community in which we operate.



The Conversion Contractors have:



a.  Provided CFS with documentation confirming they meet the fourteen (14)elements under 29 CFR Part 1910 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and 40 CFR Part 68, Section 112(r), as well as EPA's Risk Management Plan.  Contractors Mix Mobile Units also carry a PSM/RMP manual. 

 

b.  A company Emergency Action Plan and a Field Emergency Procedure/Plan.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Currently, there are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation.
